abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Resources Management Project
            in Bahia, Brazil has a satisfactory outcome, with likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development impact
            and satisfactory performances by both the Bank and the
            Borrower. Key lessons learned include: Reforms take
            considerable time and effort to build consensus and
            political support.  In dam construction the site selection
            should be based on multiple evaluation criteria and diverse
            water uses to maximize benefits while minimizing risks. An
            integrated approach to rural development in a water scarce
            semi-arid region should center on improving the availability
            of reliable water resource for the different users. The
            demand for water is beyond social and economic needs and a
            project has to cater to satisfy multiple demands. In
            addition, the overall demand for water needs to take into
            account for ecological demand to satisfy the environmental
            needs. Resettlement can be an effective instrument for
            poverty alleviation if it is participatory and the support
            is comprehensive. The existence of pilot to demonstrate to
            the potential settlers is an important ingredient to garner
            the confidence of settlers and for them to make an informed
            decision.  Contracting or outsourcing some activities is
            cost-effective and efficient, reducing the public sectors
            burden and allowing the Government to focus on its normative
            roles.  Successful piloting creates its own incentive to
            replicate the experience in other places.
